etymologies: late 17th century. From Sanskrit śaṁkha (also with vernacular pronunciation śaṁkh) shell (of a marine mollusc), especially conch shell

definitions: The large spiral shell of the gastropod mollusc Turbinella rapa found in the Indian Ocean, considered sacred in Hinduism and Buddhism; (also) the gastropod itself. In later use also: the shell of any of various other molluscs of the genus Turbinella.

notes.text: In Hinduism the shell is commonly used as a ceremonial trumpet that is sounded times of worship.

etymologies: mid 16th century; earliest use found in Arthur Golding (d. 1606), translator. Apparently a variant or alteration of champ

definitions: To chew (something), especially noisily or enthusiastically; to munch.
